verses.text: Then Samuel took a flask of oil and poured it on Saul’s head, kissed him, and said, 'Has not the Lord anointed you ruler over his inheritance?'
verses.comment: Samuel’s anointing of Saul establishes kingship through a divine calling and ritual act. Anointing with oil foreshadows later uses of anointing for priests, prophets, and ultimately, the Messiah (Christ means 'anointed one'). The act of anointing shows that leadership comes from above, not merely human ambition.

verses.text: 'When you leave me today, you will meet two men near Rachel’s tomb, on the border of Benjamin, at Zelzah. They will say to you, ‘The donkeys you went looking for have been found. Now your father has stopped worrying about the donkeys and is anxious about you. He is asking, “What shall I do about my son?”’'
verses.comment: Samuel predicts specific signs that will confirm Saul’s calling. The reference to Rachel’s tomb reminds the reader of Israel’s heritage. The change in Saul’s father’s concern also hints at the transition in Saul’s purpose from the ordinary (donkeys) to the extraordinary (rule).

verses.text: 'Then you will go on from there until you reach the oak of Tabor. Three men going up to God at Bethel will meet you there. One will be carrying three young goats, another three loaves of bread, and another a skin of wine.'
verses.comment: The three men with gifts for worship foreshadow proper sacrifice, unity, and communion. Their journey to Bethel (a place of encounter with God) symbolizes the spiritual foundation underlying Saul’s kingship.

verses.text: 'They will greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you shall accept from them.'
verses.comment: Receiving the bread is both a sign of acceptance and provision. It echoes later symbolism of bread as spiritual sustenance and priestly provision (cf. Jesus’ multiplication of loaves).

verses.text: 'After that you will come to Gibeah of God, where there is a Philistine outpost. As you are entering the town, you will meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place with harp, tambourine, flute and lyre, prophesying.'
verses.comment: The gathering of prophets foreshadows the Spirit’s work through community, music, and worship. Saul’s proximity to them anticipates his own transformation by the Spirit.

verses.text: 'The Spirit of the Lord will come on you powerfully, and you will prophesy with them, and you will be changed into a different person.'
verses.comment: The Spirit's descent transforms Saul, a prefigurement of how the Spirit works to change hearts. This closely parallels events at Pentecost, showing that the Spirit animates both leadership in the Old Testament and the Church in the New Testament era.

verses.text: 'When these signs have happened to you, do whatever your hand finds to do, for God is with you.'
verses.comment: Once endowed with the Spirit, Saul is commissioned freely, as God's presence enables him. This models faith responding to grace: the initiative of God comes first, followed by human cooperation.

verses.text: 'Go down ahead of me to Gilgal. I will come to offer burnt offerings and peace offerings. Wait seven days until I arrive and show you what to do.'
verses.comment: Samuel instructs Saul to wait for sacrificial leadership. The seven-day wait underscores obedience and liturgical timing, reminiscent of ordered worship and the importance of mediation between God and his people.

verses.text: As Saul turned to leave Samuel, God gave him a new heart, and all these signs happened that day.
verses.comment: The giving of a new heart hints at interior renewal—a theme later echoed in the promise of spiritual regeneration and sanctification. The fulfillment of signs confirms the authenticity of God’s call.

verses.text: When they reached Gibeah, a group of prophets met him, and the Spirit of God came upon him, and he prophesied with them.
verses.comment: Saul's prophetic activity aligns him with a spiritual leadership tradition, showing how the Spirit conveys authority and signalizes election. This pattern continues into New Testament ministers marked by the Spirit.

verses.text: Everyone who had known Saul previously asked, 'What’s happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?'
verses.comment: The unexpectedness of Saul’s prophetic activity demonstrates that God’s call transcends social expectations, reminiscent of Christ’s appointment of unanticipated apostles.

verses.text: A man from that place said, 'Who is their father?' So it became a saying: 'Is Saul also among the prophets?'
verses.comment: Prophecy is portrayed as a gift rather than inheritance; God can bestow spiritual gifts on whomever He chooses, regardless of lineage—foreshadowing spiritual rather than merely hereditary succession.

verses.text: After Saul finished prophesying, he went up to the high place.
verses.comment: Saul’s ascent to a sacred place, after his spiritual encounter, mirrors the pattern of communal worship and sacrificial acts in God’s service, highlighting the integration of spiritual experiences and liturgical life.

verses.text: Saul’s uncle asked him and his servant, 'Where did you go?' Saul replied, 'To look for the donkeys. When we saw they were not to be found, we went to Samuel.'
verses.comment: Saul’s conversation with family reflects the transition from normal life to divine calling. Like other biblical figures, ordinary circumstances form the backdrop for God’s extraordinary work.

verses.text: Saul’s uncle said, 'Tell me what Samuel said to you.'
verses.comment: The inquiry shows family awareness and curiosity about God’s prophet, indicating that divine messages invite investigation and dialogue (see also Jesus’ interactions with family about his mission).

verses.text: Saul replied, 'He assured us the donkeys had been found.' But he did not tell his uncle about the matter of kingship Samuel had spoken of.
verses.comment: Saul's discretion regarding his anointing reflects humility and waiting on God’s timing for public revelation of divine mysteries—a principle seen also in Christ’s progression to manifest his identity.

verses.text: Samuel summoned the people to the Lord at Mizpah.
verses.comment: The gathering at Mizpah, a site of previous renewal, signals corporate worship and covenant renewal before God, anticipating later assemblies where leaders are set apart by divine decree.

verses.text: He said to the Israelites, 'This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I brought Israel up out of Egypt and saved you from all the kingdoms that oppressed you.'
verses.comment: Samuel’s speech recalls the Exodus, pointing to God’s saving initiative as the foundation of Israel’s identity. Divine deliverance precedes and legitimizes earthly authority, a paradigm foundational to interpreting later Christian leadership.

verses.text: 'But today you have rejected your God, who saves you from all your disasters and troubles; and you have said, “No, appoint a king over us.” Now, therefore, present yourselves before the Lord by your tribes and by your clans.'
verses.comment: Demanding a king marks Israel’s lack of trust in divine providence, yet God works through their request to establish a greater plan, teaching that imperfect choices can prepare the way for fulfillment and a unifying kingdom.

verses.text: Samuel had all the tribes of Israel come forward, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen by lot.
verses.comment: The use of lots signifies divine sovereignty in choosing Saul. Benjamin’s selection stresses God’s initiative in raising up unexpected leaders.

verses.text: Then he brought forward the tribe of Benjamin, clan by clan, and Matri’s clan was chosen. Finally, Saul son of Kish was chosen. But when they looked for him, he was nowhere to be found.
verses.comment: Saul's hiddenness at his calling echoes themes of humility and reluctance to seek power, reminiscent of Moses and others who hesitated yet were called. The process also underscores the role of spiritual discernment in leadership selection.

verses.text: So they inquired of the Lord, 'Has the man come here yet?' And the Lord said, 'Yes, he has hidden himself among the baggage.'
verses.comment: Saul’s concealment further highlights humility and the sense of unworthiness, common in God’s chosen. Seeking God’s guidance in all things demonstrates the centrality of divine direction in discovery of vocation.

verses.text: They ran and brought him out, and as he stood among the people he was a head taller than anyone else.
verses.comment: Saul’s physical stature signals outward qualifications but stands in contrast with the Biblical principle that inner spiritual credentials are essential—seen in later leaders whose greatness is not merely by appearance.

verses.text: Samuel said to all the people, 'Do you see the man whom the Lord has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people.' Then the people shouted, 'Long live the king!'
verses.comment: Samuel’s acclamation points to God's unique choice. The acclamation 'Long live the king!' brings unity under authority, foreshadowing later acclamations of Christ as King by his followers.

verses.text: Then Samuel explained to the people the rights and duties of kingship, wrote it down on a scroll, and deposited it before the Lord. Then Samuel sent all the people home.
verses.comment: Samuel's instructions set the parameters for just and righteous leadership. Writing it down for public remembrance links to the tradition of apostolic teaching and the preservation of sacred doctrine within the Church. Depositing it 'before the Lord' emphasizes that divine law grounds earthly authority.

verses.text: Saul also went to his home in Gibeah, accompanied by valiant men whose hearts God had touched.
verses.comment: Those who accompany Saul have hearts moved by God, showing that spiritual unity and support among believers is fostered by the action of the Spirit. This communal dimension recalls how authentic leadership is supported by a devoted community.

verses.text: But some worthless men said, 'How can this man save us?' They despised him and gave him no gift. But Saul kept silent.
verses.comment: The rejection Saul experiences foreshadows the rejection faced by God’s chosen leaders, including Christ, who was similarly despised. Saul’s silence here is an example of the patience and forbearance often needed in vocation, urging us to trust God’s timing for vindication.
